panels.description:
This metric measures the total CPU time consumed by the container across all its cores, combining both system and user time. It provides an overall picture of CPU usage.

**Use Cases:**

* It's a common metric to gauge overall CPU consumption per container.
* Useful for setting alert thresholds to prevent over-utilization of CPU resources.
* Often used in conjunction with other CPU metrics for trend analysis and capacity planning.
panels.title: CPU / Usage (User & System)

panels.description:
This metric records the cumulative time spent by the container's CPU in user mode. User mode represents time spent executing application code rather than operating system kernel code.

**Use Cases:**

* Useful for analyzing the CPU time consumed by applications and processes within the container itself.

* High values can indicate that the application is performing significant computation, making it suitable for performance profiling and optimization.
panels.title: CPU / User

panels.description:
This metric records the cumulative time spent by the container's CPU in system (kernel) mode. System mode represents time spent on kernel-level operations, such as handling I/O requests or managing system calls.

**Use Cases:**

* Useful to identify when containers are spending too much time in the kernel, which could indicate inefficiencies in system calls or potential issues with I/O operations.
* Monitoring this can help detect whether excessive system overhead affects container performance.
panels.title: CPU / System

panels.description:
Total memory usage, including all memory in use by the container (active, cached, etc.). This provides a high-level view of memory consumption.

**Use Cases:**

* Useful for tracking overall memory footprint.
* Allows you to monitor and manage the container’s total memory consumption and detect any sudden increases that might indicate memory leaks.
panels.title: Memory Usage Bytes

panels.description:
Memory that is actively used by the container, excluding cache and unused memory. This shows the actual memory demand of the container.

**Use Cases:**

* Indicates the real memory demand of a container.
* Helps prevent over-provisioning, as this metric focuses on memory actually being used for active processes rather than cached or unused memory.
panels.title: Memory Working Set

panels.description:
Peak memory usage since the container started. This helps in understanding historical maximum memory demand, useful for right-sizing containers.

**Use Cases:**

* Useful for capacity planning and identifying if a container’s memory usage spikes close to its limits.
* Helps you assess historical memory demands and adjust container memory allocation accordingly.
panels.title: Memory Max Usage Bytes

panels.description:
Resident Set Size memory, representing non-swappable physical memory used by the container. This is memory that is actively in use and cannot be swapped out.

**Use Cases:**

* Shows memory that cannot be swapped to disk and is essential for the container’s operation.
* Helpful to monitor for assessing memory pressure, as high RSS usage may mean the container is approaching its memory limit.
panels.title: Memory Resident Set Size

panels.description:
Cached memory, which includes data the container has used and stored in RAM for faster access. This memory can be freed if necessary.

**Use Cases:**

* Cached memory can be freed when needed, so high cache usage is generally not a concern.
* Monitoring cache usage helps distinguish between memory actively in use and memory that can be freed.
panels.title: Memory Cached

panels.description:
Memory used for memory-mapped files, often used for accessing large files quickly. This provides insight into specific types of memory allocation used by the container.

**Use Cases:**

* Useful in understanding memory consumption related to memory-mapped file usage, common in applications that access large files frequently.
* Allows fine-tuning if memory-mapped files significantly contribute to memory usage.
panels.title: Memory Mapped File

panels.description:
Memory used by kernel processes on behalf of the container, such as system calls or kernel space processes.

**Use Cases:**

* Helpful in monitoring memory consumed by kernel processes on behalf of the container.
* High kernel memory usage might suggest a high rate of system calls or other kernel-intensive operations within the container.
panels.title: Memory Kernel Usage

panels.description:
Amount of swap memory used by the container, indicating when it exceeds physical memory limits.

**Use Cases:**

* Indicates when the container has exceeded its physical memory limits and is using swap, which can lead to performance degradation.
* High swap usage can indicate that more RAM should be allocated or that the container’s memory limits should be adjusted.
panels.title: Memory Swap

panels.description:
Count of memory allocation failures due to reaching memory limits. Useful for identifying if the container’s memory settings are too restrictive.

**Use Cases:**

* Helps in identifying memory bottlenecks in real-time.
* Provides insight into whether memory limits are too restrictive for the container’s needs.
panels.title: Memory Allocation Failures Count

panels.description:
Total count of all memory allocation failures, offering a broader view of memory pressure within the container.

**Use Cases:**

* Useful for detecting memory pressure within the container, indicating when it couldn’t allocate more memory.
* Helps troubleshoot memory limits and evaluate if more memory should be allocated to prevent application failures.
panels.title: Memory Allocation Failures Total

panels.description:
Cumulative I/O usage for block devices, typically representing the number of I/O operations or the amount of data (in bytes) read from or written to storage devices associated with the container.

**Use Cases:**

* Performance Monitoring: Helps monitor storage performance, especially important for I/O-intensive applications that frequently read and write data to disk.
* Troubleshooting: High values in block I/O metrics may indicate heavy disk usage, which could lead to performance bottlenecks, especially in shared or limited storage environments.
* Capacity Planning: Useful for understanding the container's disk utilization patterns and planning resource allocation based on usage trends.
panels.title: Block I/O (Input/Output)
